verdict.summary: The referenced table does not exist in the specified database. Common causes include missing migrations, connecting to the wrong database, case sensitivity issues on Linux (MySQL table names are case-sensitive on case-sensitive filesystems), or InnoDB tablespace corruption.

dead_ends.action: Changing lower_case_table_names after the database has been initialized
dead_ends.why_fails: lower_case_table_names must be set before MySQL data directory initialization. Changing it on an existing instance with mixed-case table names causes existing tables to become inaccessible.

dead_ends.action: Copying .ibd tablespace files from another MySQL instance directly
dead_ends.why_fails: InnoDB tablespace files are tied to the specific MySQL instance's data dictionary. Simply copying .ibd files without proper IMPORT TABLESPACE procedure causes corruption errors.

workarounds.action: Run pending migrations to create the missing table
workarounds.how: Run the application's migration tool (e.g., 'php artisan migrate', 'npx sequelize db:migrate', 'rails db:migrate'). Verify the table exists: SHOW TABLES LIKE 'my_table';

workarounds.action: Check the database name and table name case sensitivity
workarounds.how: On Linux, MySQL table names are case-sensitive. Run: SHOW TABLES; to list actual table names. Verify you are in the correct database: SELECT DATABASE(); Use the exact case in queries. If developing cross-platform, set lower_case_table_names=1 at initialization time.

leads_to.condition: when attempting to run migrations but they fail due to other dependency issues

preceded_by.condition: when user connects to wrong database after fixing access issues

frequently_confused_with.distinction: MySQL says 'Table doesn't exist' while PostgreSQL says 'relation does not exist'. MySQL error includes the database name prefix (mydb.my_table) which PostgreSQL does not.
